comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Possibly the Nancy Steele who was a debutante the year before. NYT of Nov 28, 1912 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9507E3DF103CE633A... If so, she was the 2nd daughter of Mrs. Charles Steele, who had a country home, Sunridge, in Westbury, Long Island. NYT of July 22, 1913 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9B06E2DD163DE633A... indicates that her wedding to Devereux Milburn would take place on November 1, 1913. The date written is hard to decipher but appears to me to be 11/3/13.

comment._content: pennylrichardsca:  Thanks for bringing to our attention to the identities of the Steele sisters.  We'll be able to update a few records with this information.

comment.author: 79638854@N07
comment._content: The Seattle Daily Times, Saturday Evening,November 1, 1913, Page Three, Courtesy of Genealogy Bank (picture of couple included with article) Devereux Milburn, Crack Polo Player, Weds Sport-Loving Miss Nancy Steele New York, Nov. 1 – The little Episcopal church at Westbury, L.I., was the scene today of the wedding of Miss Nancy Steele and Devereux Milburn, the crack polo player who was the star of the American polo team in England in 1909 and one of the most notable defenders of the cup at the International contest in this city a few weeks ago. The marriage ceremony which was witnessed only by a few friends and relatives of the couple, was followed by a reception at Sunridge Hall, the country residence of the bride’s parents, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Steele. A special train from New York carried many guests to the reception and the hunting set of Long Island was well represented. The news of the engagement in June came as a surprise, as few outside of the immediate families of the young couple knew that a deeper sentiment than a mutual interest in sports existed between them. Miss Steele’s father is a member of the firm of J.P. Morgan & Co. Milburn is a member of the Meadowbrook, the Aero and the Racket and Tennis Clubs. He was graduated from Oxford in 1903 and from Harvard in 1906. He was star of the American polo team in England in 1909 and again in 1910 and distinguished himself in the last international series. He has long been noted for his daring horsemanship.

comment.author: 33593953@N02
comment._content: Thanks for the information about the event (and for including your source!).  It will enable us to update the description more precisely.
